title-group.article-title: Nonlinear dynamics of a rotor-ball bearing system with Alford force

article-meta.aff: 1State Key Laboratory of Mechanical System and Vibration, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, People′s Republic of China
2Shanghai Baosteel Equipment Maintenance Co. Ltd., Shanghai, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Mei Cheng, State Key Laboratory of Mechanical System and Vibration, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, 800 Dongchuan RD, Shanghai, 200240, People’s Republic of China Email: chengmei1206@163.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The nonlinear dynamic behaviors of an unbalanced rotor system supported on ball bearings with Alford force are investigated. In the rotor model, the rotor unbalance that varied with rotating speed, ball bearing clearance, nonlinear Hertzian contact force, varying compliance vibration, contact angle and Alford force are considered. The bifurcation of the rotor system is analyzed under different operating conditions. It is indicated that the dynamic behavior of the rotor system depends on the rotation speed and ball bearing clearance. The system state trajectory, Poincaré maps, frequency spectra and bifurcation diagrams are constructed to analyze the dynamic behavior of the rotor center. Various nonlinear phenomena in the coupled system, such as periodic motion, quasi-periodic motion and chaotic motion are investigated. The study may contribute to a further understanding of the nonlinear dynamics of such a rotor system.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Dynamic phenomena induced by interaction between the rotor and ball bearing or Alford force and creating severe rotor vibration have been recognized for many years. High amplitude shaft vibration which can sustain themselves over a wide range of rotational speeds not only perturb the normal operation of a rotating machine, but may also cause serious damage to the machine and the entire plant.

Nowadays, the literature related to a rotor supported on oil sliding bearing phenomena is abundant. However, the dynamic model of a rotor supported on ball bearing is still very immature (Chen et al., 2004; Choi and Part, 2001; Jing and Meng, 2004; Jing et al., 2005; Liu et al., 2005).Yamamoto (1955) worked on the rotor dynamic supported by ball bearings with radial clearances, but not the varying compliance vibrations. Fukata et al. (1985) fist took up the study of varying compliance vibrations and the nonlinear dynamic response for the ball bearing supporting a balanced horizontal rotor with a constant vertical force. Mevel and Guyader (1993) also developed a theoretical model of a ball bearing supporting a balanced horizontal rigid rotor, with a constant vertical radial force. But, in these studies, the effect of rotor unbalance was not considered. The studies under taken by Day (1987) and Kim and Noah (1996) considered the effect of unbalanced force only, but not a varying compliance effect. Harsha (2005a,b, 2006a,b) studied the effects of radial internal clearance for both balanced an unbalanced rotors. The combined effect of unbalance, bearing clearance, nonlinear Hertzian contact force, and the varying compliance vibrations were studied by Tiwari and Gupta (2000). However, the unbalance force was considered as a constant force in the research. In the analysis of Chen (2009), the unbalanced rotor, the varying compliance vibrations and the radial internal clearance are studied in addition to nonlinearity due to Hertzian contact, but not the variation of the contact angle. Therefore, considering the rotor unbalance that varies with rotating speed, ball bearing clearance, nonlinear Hertzian contact force, varying compliance vibrations and contact angle, a dynamic model of the rotor-ball bearing is established in this study.

Many sources of self-excited vibrations in a rotor system (e.g., asymmetric bearing stiffness and non-axisymmetric clearance in labyrinth seals) have been identified and extensively analyzed by investigators such Benckert and Wachter (1982), as Childs (1993) and Millsaps (1992). However, the rotordynamic forces due to non-axisymmetric clearance in turbines and compressors have received relatively little attention. As for the Alford force model, the model of Chai et al. (2001) not only educes the design parameters of vane but also has solved the difficulty of selecting the efficiency factor in the Alford formulation, and it is employed in this study.

In the research on the dynamics of a compressor rotor system, only a single factor, ball bearing or Alford force, is taken into account. The method will cause the results to deviate from the facts. The compressor rotor system is supported by ball bearings. And, the Alford force, induced by a nonuniform tip clearance when the compressor rotor is whirling, is acquired. Then the combined effect of the Alford force and ball bearing are significant on the dynamic characteristics and stability of the rotor system. Therefore, it is important to investigate the effects of ball bearing force and Alford force on the structural response of a compressor rotor system and model them in one numerical model.

As a result, the rotor system is modeled by considering the nonlinear ball bearing force and Alford force simultaneously to analyze the coupling complicated nonlinear vibrations. This paper is divided into four sections. In Section 2, a mathematical model is developed, and the nonlinearity of the ball bearing and the Alford force considered. Section 3 obtained rotor responses by numerical integration, and the effects of rotating speed and ball bearing clearance on system responses are studied. Section 4 draws some brief conclusions.

sec.title: Mathematical Model
sec.p:
The key point is to analyze the influence of the nonlinear ball bearing force and Alford force in the paper. As a result, it makes an assumption that the torsional vibration of rotor and gyroscopic effects may be neglected and only the transverse vibration of rotor should be considered. Thus the rotor system can be modeled as a Jeffcott rotor system, in which the rotor is simplified to one disk with two transverse stiffness and the masses of the shaft being equivalent to the disk and two bearings. The model of rotor system is shown in Figure 1. The two ends of this rotor are supported on similar ball bearings. Figure 1.
A rotor-ball bearing system.

sec.title: Governing Equations
sec.p: The mathematical model of the rotor system takes into account 4 degrees-of-freedom —horizontal and vertical displacements of the rotor at the disk location (X1,Y1) and at the ball bearing (X2,Y2), correspondingly. After assembling the Alford force and ball bearing force, the dynamic equations of the system are established as follows: (1)

sec.title: Nonlinear Ball Bearing Force
sec.p:
The ball bearing model considered here has equispaced balls rolling on the surfaces of the inner and outer races. It is assumed that the outer race is fixed rigidly to the support and the inner race is fixed rigidly to the shaft and there is no bending of races. There is perfect rolling of balls on the races so that the two points of the ball (A and B) touching the outer and inner races have different linear velocities, as shown in Figure 2, and the tangent velocity of the contact point between the ball and the inner race VA, outer race VB, respectively, can be given by (2) (3) Figure 2.
Ball bearing.
And the tangent velocity of the cage is (4)
Because the inner race is fixed to the shaft, ωB = ωrotor. Then, the angular velocity of the cage is given by (5)
The varying compliance frequency or the ball passage frequency can be described as the cage speed times the number of balls. (6)
Where (7)
The number BN depends on the dimensions of the bearing.
The expression for the total displacement of the centre of the inner race δj is given as follows: (8)
The angular position of the jth ball θj at time t can be defined as (9)
The contact angle of ball bearing (Bai et al., 2008) is (10)

The ball-race contact deformation of the ball generates a restoring force with nonlinear characteristics because of the Hertzian contact. At the same time, if the contact deformation is positive, the contact force could be determined using the Hertzian contact theory (Harris, 1984); otherwise, no load is transmitted. So the contact force between the jth ball and inner race can be expressed as (11)
The value of Cb is arrived at by performing theelastic analysis of the Hertzian contact between the inner and outer race and the ball (Harris, 1984).
The total restoring force is the sum of the restoring force from each of the rolling elements.Thus, the total restoring force components in the X2 and Y2 directions are (12)

sec.title: Alford Force
sec.p: Based on the hydrodynamics, the air exciting-vibration force of turbomachinery caused by clearance is studied by using the momentum theorem (Chai et al., 2001). The computational formulation consisted of the design parameters of vane is educed and it has solved the difficulty of selecting the efficiency factor in the Alford formulation. The model was introduced in reference (Chai et al., 2001): (13) where I1 and I2 are in relation to the inlet angle and outlet angle and were described in detail in Chai et al. (2001).
For the convenience of calculating composition, the dimensionless transformations are given as follows: (14)
Equations (12) and (13) are substituted into equation (1), equation (1) becomes: (15)
Where

sec.title: Numerical Analysis
sec.p:
The responses of the rotor-ball bearing system with the Alford force become more complicated when combining the Alford force with the nonlinear ball bearing force. The numerical integration method is considered as a straightforward method to show motion orbit of the rotor, especially in a complicated motion. The fourth-order Runge-Kutta method was used to integrate the equation (Li et al., 2003). The time step for the direct numerical integration is π / 500 and the error tolerance is less than 0.001. Long time-marching computation is required to obtain a convergent orbit.Dates of former 800 revolutions are not used for dynamic behavior investigation. Thereby the data analyzed is steady state. The main partial parameters of numerical calculation are written as follows: L = 360 mm, D = 370 mm, M1 = 12.1 kg, M2 = 2.0 kg, C1 = 700 Ns/m, C2 = 300 Ns/m, K = 8 × 106 N/s, e = 0.05 mm. The 61903 ball bearing in Fukata et al. (1985) is chosen as the ball bearing in this paper, and its parameters are listed in Table 1. The main parameters of the Alford force (Chai et al., 2001) are listed in Table 2. Table 1.
The main parameters of the 61903 ball bearing
Distance between bearing center and outer race RA (mm) Distance between bearing center and inner race RB (mm) Inner race radius of curvature Ri (mm) Outer race radius of curvature Ro (mm)
14.13 9.37 2.401 2.52
Number of balls N Contact stiffness Cb (N/m3/2) Bearing clearance r0 (mm) BN
9 7.055 × 109 0.04 3.59
Table 2.
The main parameters of Alford force
Relative velocities of airflow on the leading edge ν 1 (m/s) Density of airflow ρ 0 (kg/m3) Radium of vane tip R (mm) Radium of vane bottom r (mm) Velocity factor ψ Average clearance of vane tip δ¯ (mm)
350 11.8 500 370 0.83 1.2

sec.title: Analysis Method
sec.p: To illustrate the numerical results, the following plots are used:

Bifurcation diagram. The bifurcation diagram exhibits continuous changes of motion states for the dynamic system. It provides a summary of the essential dynamics and is a useful way to observe the nonlinear dynamic behavior. The control parameter has a constant variation. The variation of return points in the Poincaré map of dimensionless time is then plotted against the control parameter, which generates the bifurcation diagram.

Poincaré map. A Poincaré section is a stroboscopic picture of motion in a phase plane and it consists of points in time at a constant interval of T (T = 2π/ω). The point on the Poincaré section is referred to as a return point. The projection of a Poincaré section on the X(nT)-Y(nT) plane is referred to as the Poincaré map of the motion, which indicates the nature of the motion. Characteristics of different typical motion states in the Poincaré map are shown in Table 3. Table 3.
Motion characteristic in Poincaré map
Motion state Poincaré map
Synchronous Single point
KT-periodic K discrete points
Quasi-periodic Closured curve formed by infinite points
Chaotic Dense points with the geometrically fractal structure
Frequency spectrum. The frequency spectrum of the Y-coordinate is computed.

sec.title: Influence of Rotating Speed
sec.p:
Rotational speed is one of the key parameters affecting the dynamic characteristics of a rotor system. Figure 3 shows the frequency spectrum for ω = 300 rpm. Because the rotating speed is very low, the unbalance force is very weak. It can be found that the varying compliance frequency and its harmonics dominate in the system frequency spectrum. Figure 3.
Spectrum of frequency (ω = 300 rpm).

Figure 4 is the projection of the Poincaré section and the frequency spectrum for the rotating speed ω = 3000 rpm. There are two discrete frequency components in the frequency spectrum and a closed circle in the projection of the Poincaré section, which represents quasi-periodic. As the rotating speed continues to increase, the motion demonstrates different phenomena. Figure 5 gives the projection of the Poincaré section and the frequency spectrum for the rotating speed ω = 10000 rpm. Because the rotating speed is close to the first-order critical speed, the rotating frequency components increase quickly, the varying compliance frequency components and the combination frequency components decrease relatively. There is an isolated point in the Poincaré section, the rotating frequency component in the frequency spectrum. All of these prove that the motion is period-one motion. When the rotating speed increases to 15000 rpm, the response is shown in Figure 6. In the frequency spectrum (see Figure 6(b)), the peak amplitude appears at the half of rotating frequency, because of the Alford force, induced by the nonuniform tip clearance. Pieces of dispersed points like a cloudlet come forth in the Poincaré maps, as shown in Figure 6(a). Obviously, the Alford force induces the rotor system to lose stability. The rotor system shifts into a chaotic state. Figure 4.
Quasi-periodic motion at ω = 3000 rpm: (a) Poincaré map (b) spectrum of frequency. Figure 5.
Periodic motion at ω = 10000 rpm: (a) Poincaré map (b) spectrum of frequency. Figure 6.
Chaotic motion at ω = 15000 rpm: (a) Poincaré map (b) spectrum of frequency.

sec.title: Influence of Ball Bearing Clearance
sec.p:
Ball bearing clearance is also one of the key factors affecting the dynamic characteristics of the system. So it is very essential to study its influences on the dynamic characteristics of the system. Figures 7, 8, 18 and 19 are the bifurcation diagrams of the system with different ball bearing clearance, in which the rotating speed is treated as the control parameter. The bifurcation characteristics of r0 = 1 µm were shown in Figure 7. It can be seen that the motion of the rotor system with less rotation speed (ω < 4700 rpm) is quasi-periodic (see Figure 9) because of the concurrence of the rotating frequency component and the varying compliance frequency component. When the rotating speed is higher than 4700 rpm, because the varying compliance vibration of the system is relatively weak, the system motion is synchronous with period-one (see Figure 10) and the system does not appear chaotic motion. When ball bearing r0 = 10 µm, its bifurcation characteristics are shown in Figure 8. The system presents obviously complex dynamic characters. Figure 7.
Bifurcation diagram with the increasing rotation speed (r0 = 1 µm). Figure 8.
Bifurcation diagram with the increasing rotation speed (r0 = 10 µm). Figure 9.
Quasi-periodic motion at ω = 4500 rpm: (a) orbit of rotor center, (b) Poincaré map (c) spectrum of frequency. Figure 10.
Periodic motion at ω = 11000 rpm: (a) orbit of rotor center, (b) Poincaré map (c) spectrum of frequency.

The responses (Figures 11 to 17) are further analyzed by the projections of the Poincaré map, the rotor center trajectory and the frequency spectrum. Figure 11 shows the trajectory of rotor center, the projection of the Poincaré section and the frequency spectrum for the rotating speed ω = 4500 rpm. The frequency spectrum has a band structure as seen in between spikes of the rotating frequency, half of the rotating frequency and their multiples. And the orbit at this speed does not repeat itself as shown in Figure 11(a). At the same time, pieces of dispersed points like a cloudlet come forth in the Poincaré maps. As a result, the rotor system is chaos. When the rotating speed ω = 11000 rpm is near the first-order critical speed, the unbalance response is large enough to ignore the ball passage vibrations, as shown in Figure 12. It gives the trajectory of rotor center, the projection of the Poincaré section and the frequency spectrum. There is an isolated pointing the Poincaré section, the rotating frequency component in the frequency spectrum and a limited circle in the trajectory map, which represents period-one motion. As the rotating speed gradually increases (see Figure 13), the motion is similar to those in Figure 11. Namely, there is chaotic motion. The rotor trajectory is irregular. As the rotating speed continues to increase, period-doubling appears in Figure 14 and the chaotic nature reduces. There are two isolated points in the Poincaré section. The rotor trajectory shows 2T periodic motion. When the rotating speed ω = 26000 rpm (see Figure 15), the rotor center trajectory is a limited circle and one discrete frequency component in the frequency spectrum. Obviously, the system is a periodic motion. When the rotating speed is around 27500 rpm, in Figure 16, period one solution becomes multi-orbit unstable, there are three isolated points in the Poincaré map. This is a typical 3T periodic motion. Finally, the system gets into the chaotic regime again (see Figure 17). Figure 11.
Chaos motion at ω = 4500 rpm: (a) orbit of rotor center, (b) Poincaré map (c) spectrum of frequency. Figure 12.
Periodic motion at ω = 11000 rpm: (a) orbit of rotor center, (b) Poincaré map (c) spectrum of frequency. Figure 13.
Chaos motion at ω = 21000 rpm: (a) orbit of rotor center, (b) Poincaré map (c) spectrum of frequency. Figure 14.
2T Periodic motion at ω = 22000 rpm: (a) orbit of rotor center, (b) Poincaré map (c) spectrum of frequency. Figure 15.
Periodic motion at ω = 26000 rpm: (a) orbit of rotor center, (b) Poincaré map (c) spectrum of frequency. Figure 16.
3T Periodic motion at ω = 27500 rpm: (a) orbit of rotor center, (b) Poincaré map (c) spectrum of frequency. Figure 17.
Chaos motion at ω = 29500 rpm: (a) orbit of rotor center, (b) Poincaré map (c) spectrum of frequency.

Figures 18 and 19 are the system bifurcation with ball bearing clearance of 30 µm and 50 µm, respectively. Via the comparison of the bifurcation plots (see Figures 7, 8, 18 and 19), it can be found that with the ball bearing clearance increasing, the quasi-periodic and chaos motions enlarge gradually. So it can be concluded from the above-described dynamic phenomena, the ball bearing clearance has an important effect on the stability of the system. Figure 18.
Bifurcation diagram with the increasing rotation speed (r0 = 30 µm). Figure 19.
Bifurcation diagram with the increasing rotation speed (r0 = 50 µm).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
Considering the rotor unbalance that varies with rotating speed, ball bearing clearance, nonlinear Hertzian contact force, varying compliance vibration, contact angle and the Alford force, a dynamic model of the rotor-ball bearing with the Alford force is put forward to analyze the complicated nonlinear vibrations of a rotor system. The conclusions drawn from the study can be summarized as follows:
The Alford force, induced by the nonuniform tip clearance when the rotor is whirling, provokes the emergence of the half of rotating frequency components, and induces the rotor system to lose stability.
Some nonlinear analysis methods are employed to explore dynamic behaviors of the discussed system, including bifurcation diagrams, dynamic orbit, Poincaré map and frequency spectrum. The results show that the system exhibits rich forms of periodic, quasi-periodic and chaotic motions.
The effect of the rotating speed on the rotor system responses is analyzed, and many combination frequency components of rotating frequency and the varying compliance frequency are found with rotating speed increasing gradually.
Ball bearing clearance is the key factor affecting the dynamic characteristics of the rotor-ball bearing system. Numerical analysis shows the rotor system of the quasi-periodic and chaos motions are more and wider and worse the stability of the system with the ball bearing clearance increasing. Therefore, in the process of design and operation of the ball bearing, it is important to effectively control the ball bearing clearance.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by Project supported by the Research Fund of State Key Lab of MSV, China [Grant No. MSV-MS-2010-9]; The project was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China [No. 10732060]; and The project was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China [No. 10572087].
